title: ISO 31000:2018 - Enterprise Risk Management Framework for Risk Leaders
headline: In this free online course learn the basic principles, framework and processes of risk management for ISO 31000:2018.
description: This free online ISO 31000 course teaches you the principles and fundamental concepts of risk management. You will understand the various terms included in the ISO GUIDE 73 on risk management, the relationship of various principles, frameworks and processes as well as the role of leadership in creating and managing risk management frameworks for different organizations.
courseDescription:
ISO 31000 is the international risk management framework standard for enterprises and corporations. This free online course empowers you to support and lead an organization and its team to robustly identify, comprehend and manage a risk process based on ISO 31000: 2018. You will learn risk management best practices that include the starting point for designing, implementing, monitoring, reviewing and continually enhancing the risk management process. 

This interactive course explores the International Standard Organization’s (ISO) complex guidelines in a practical way and starts by introducing the 31000 standard. Its scope, definitions and various other applicable publications are discussed. Also included are other important terminologies of risk management that are listed in the ISO Guide 73:2009. Critical to the successful implementation of a risk management framework is the integration of it into an organization’s systems and processes. Stakeholder inclusion, continual improvement and leadership buy-in are all vital to ensure adequate resource allocation and effective implementation. The material covers all of these aspects and many more, and practically demonstrates how a framework should be designed with specific provision for evaluation and feedback. The next part covers risk management at different levels, which happens once the initial framework has been implemented. You will learn about communication and consultation, how to build inclusiveness in the teams involved in implementation and the role of scope definition in the implementation process. Risk criteria plays a vital role in the risk assessment process and once you learn about them, you will cover the decisions that need to be made as far as risk treatment options go and the many recommendations there could be.

This free online course is ideal for those in risk management roles or mid-to-senior management level employees who are key to strategic decision making. Enrolling for this course will allow you to expand your knowledge and skills in the critical and sought-after area of risk management.

Start Course Now

slides:
• Learning Outcomes
  • After successfully completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Define the ISO 31000:2018 Risk Management Standard and its Scope.
    • Summarize the concept of Risk Management & its Connection with Human Nature & Cultural Aspect.
    • State the terms and definitions in the Standard.
    • Discuss the primary constituents of risk.
    • List the terms and definitions in the ISO GUIDE 73 regarding Risk Management.
    • Describe the Principles of Risk Management.
  • Understanding Risk
  • Risk is the uncertainty found in business objectives. An organization can view it based on  three possible dimensions. The three dimensions are opportunities, neutral perspective, and negative perspective which focuses on harmful effects.

  • Basic Terms Related to Risk Management
  • Some of the basic terms are:
    • New Tab
      Enter your text here..
      Enter your text here..
    • Risk (Clause - 3.1)
      Risk is defined in Clause - 3.1 as the "effect of uncertainty on objectives."

      It is important to note that an effect of uncertainty is a change from the anticipated result. Risk can be both positive or negative and can result in other opportunities and threats. Objectives can have various aspects and categories and can be implemented at various levels and business functions. Risk is usually elaborated in terms of risk sources, potential events, consequences, and likelihood.
      Risk is defined in Clause - 3.1 as the "effect of uncertainty on objectives."

Objectives can have various aspects and categories and can be implemented at various levels and business functions. Risk is usually elaborated in terms of risk sources, potential events, consequences, and likelihood.
    • Risk Management (Clause - 3.2)
      Risk management is defined in Clause - 3.2 as "coordinated activities to direct and control an organization with regard to risk."

    • Risk Management Framework is defined as a "set of components that provide the foundations and organizational arrangements for designing, implementing, monitoring, reviewing and continually improving risk management throughout the organization."

      • The foundations incorporate the risk management commitment, policy, and objectives.
      • The organizational arrangements comprise resources, activities, processes, plans, accountability, relationships, etc.
      • The risk management framework is implanted in the company's strategic and base-level policies and practices.

  • Lesson Summary
    • Managing risk is a systematic process. It empowers organizations to make strategy, acquire business objectives, and make calculated and informed decisions.
    • This standard can be utilized throughout the organization's existence and can be implemented in any process, activity, business function, and decision-making at all different levels.
    • Risk management is an important sector of all activities linked with a company and includes an interchange with collaborators.
    • Terms & Definitions in ISO GUIDE 73 on Risk Management
      -       Risk Management Framework: "set of components that provide the foundations and organizational arrangements for designing, implementing, monitoring, reviewing and continually improving risk management throughout the organization."
      -       Risk Management Process: "systematic application of management policies, procedures, and practices to the activities of communicating, consulting, establishing the context, and identifying, analyzing, evaluating, treating, monitoring and reviewing risk."
      -       Stakeholder: "person or organization that can affect, be affected by, or perceive themselves to be affected by a decision or activity."
      -       Risk Assessment: "overall process of risk identification, risk analysis, and risk evaluation."

  • Learning Outcomes
  • After successfully completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Describe the Risk Management Framework.
    • Summarize the roles and responsibilities of the top management and oversight bodies regarding Leadership & Commitment.
    • Outline the concepts of Integration of Risk Management Framework and the designing and development of the Framework.
    • Explain the Framework's Implementation, Evaluation of the Framework's effectiveness, and its Continual Improvement considerations.
    • Define the Risk Management Process.
    • Discuss the purpose and aims of Communication & Consultation, and Scope, Context, & Criteria in Risk Management Process.
    • Describe the process of Risk Assessment and Risk Treatment.
    • Discuss the aims and considerations of Monitoring & Review and Recording & Reporting.
  • Framework (Clause - 5)
    • The risk management framework's main objective is to empower the organization to integrate and align risk management into important activities and processes. The results of risk management will be reliant on its integration in various aspects of the organization. The aspects can include governance of the organization, including decision-making. This also mandates empowerment from stakeholders, especially top management.
    • Framework development encompasses integrating, designing, implementing, evaluating, and improving risk management across the organization (Illustration 3 on the next page shows the framework's components).
    • The organization should also comprehensively assess its present risk management practices and processes, identify gaps, and resolve those gaps within the framework.
    • The components and units of the framework and how they collaborate should be tailored to the organization's requirements.

    • The organization should also comprehensively assess its present risk management practices and processes, identify gaps, and resolve those gaps within the framework.
    • The components and units of the framework and how they collaborate should be tailored to the organization's requirements.

  • Process (Clause - 6)
    • The risk management process incorporates the systematic implementation of practices, policies, and procedures. This will encompass proceedings for communication and consultation, analyze the organization's context, and continue with assessment, treatment, evaluation, record keeping, and reporting of risk (Process is shown in Illustration 4 on next page).
    • The risk management process needs to be an integral part of the management and decision-making process and integrated into the organization's structure, processes, and operations. It can be implemented at any level, such as project, program, strategic, or operational levels.
    • There can be many prospects for implementing the risk management process within an organization. It can be tailored to achieve business objectives and to match the organization's external and internal context.
    • The energetic and inconsistent nature of human behavior and culture should be reflected throughout the risk management process.
    • Although the risk management process is at times exhibited as sequential, in reality, it should be iterative.

  • Risk evaluation (Clause - 6.6.4)
    • New Tab
    • Purpose of Risk Evaluation
    • Decisions and Outcomes
    • Enter your text here..
      Enter your text here..
    • The focus of risk evaluation is to help in making decisions. Risk evaluation involves comparing the results of the risk analysis with the developed risk criteria to identify whether additional action is required or not. This can lead to a decision to:

      • Work as it is and no need for a specific action as risk is in acceptable range
      • Ponder on the risk treatment options
      • Carry on additional analysis to better comprehend the risk
      • Keep current controls
      • Make new achievable objectives and leave the unrealistic current ones.
      The focus of risk evaluation is to help in making decisions. Risk evaluation involves comparing the results of the risk analysis with the developed risk criteria to identify whether additional action is required or not. This can lead to a decision to:

      • Work as it is and no need for a specific action as risk is in acceptable range
      • Ponder on the risk treatment options
      • Carry on additional analysis to better comprehend the risk
      • Keep current controls
      • Make new achievable objectives and leave the unrealistic current ones.
    • Decisions should reflect the extensive context along with the actual and anticipated consequences to stakeholders, both external or internal.

      The outcome of risk evaluation should be documented in records, communicated, and then authenticated at relevant levels of the organization.

    • Purpose of Risk Evaluation
      The focus of risk evaluation is to help in making decisions. Risk evaluation involves comparing the results of the risk analysis with the developed risk criteria to identify whether additional action is required or not. This can lead to a decision to:

      • Work as it is and no need for a specific action as risk is in acceptable range
      • Ponder on the risk treatment options
      • Carry on additional analysis to better comprehend the risk
      • Keep current controls
      • Make new achievable objectives and leave the unrealistic current ones.

      The focus of risk evaluation is to help in making decisions. Risk evaluation involves comparing the results of the risk analysis with the developed risk criteria to identify whether additional action is required or not. This can lead to a decision to:

      • Work as it is and no need for a specific action as risk is in acceptable range
      • Ponder on the risk treatment options
      • Carry on additional analysis to better comprehend the risk
      • Keep current controls
      • Make new achievable objectives and leave the unrealistic current ones.

  • Lesson Summary
    • Framework (Clause - 5)
      - The main objective of the risk management framework is to empower the organization in integrating and aligning risk management into important activities and processes. The results of risk management will be reliant on its integration in various aspects of the organization. The aspects can include governance of the organization, including decision-making. This also mandates empowerment from stakeholders, especially top management.
      - Framework development encompasses integrating, designing, implementing, evaluating and improving risk management across the organization.
      - Integrating risk management into an organization is a dynamic and iterative process, and should be customized to the organization’s needs and culture.
      - Allocating Resources (Clause - 5.4.4): Top management and oversight bodies, where applicable, should ensure allocation of appropriate resources for risk management, which can include, but are not limited to people, skills, experience and competence.
      - The organization should implement the risk management framework by ensuring that the organization’s arrangements for managing risk are clearly understood and practiced.
      - In order to evaluate the effectiveness of the risk management framework, the organization should periodically measure risk management framework performance against its purpose, implementation plans, indicators and expected behavior.
      - Adapting (Clause - 5.7.1): The organization should continually monitor and adapt the risk management framework to address external and internal changes.
